newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Prodi sees further "very slight" CPI falls.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Prodi sees further "very slight" CPI falls.

text.p: Prime Minister Romano Prodi said on Wednesday that Italian consumer price inflation would continue to register "very slight" falls and ruled out a reversal of the downward trend of recent months.

"Inflation is now at 2.6 to 2.7 percent," Prodi said in a speech to a Business International seminar in Rome. "It is a trend that is not going to be reversed but will continue, even if very slightly, to improve," he said.

Official November consumer price inflation data is due out on December 5. Analysts expect it to show year-on-year inflation of 2.6 percent, based on provisional data for the month released by 10 Italian cities last week, after October's 3.0 percent.
Bank of Italy action on cutting official interest rates is linkly firmly to the battle to tame inflation.
Prodi's centre-left government has set an official target of 2.5 percent for 1997. CPI inflation has fallen over the past 12 months from 6.0 percent to levels unseen in Italy since 1969.
